data.author: Bob333
data.content: CONT: In short, the message is: the policy clouds have cleared, Buchan is being optimised rather than rushed, JOG’s big partners are getting even bigger, and JOG itself is lean, funded, carried on Buchan and hunting deals that monetise its tax shield. DYOR!

data.author: Bob333
data.content: Big picture •	Government has finished its long consultations, so the rules on environment and tax are now known, which lets companies plan long term projects like Buchan more sensibly. •	JOG’s partners (NEO and Serica) have bulked up via M&A, making Buchan part of two much larger, better capitalised UK North Sea portfolios. •	JOG itself has cut costs, has no debt, a modest but adequate cash pile, and a fully carried 20% stake in Buchan plus a further milestone payment due at FDP approval. UK tax and regulation •	Environmental rules now require Buchan to include Scope 3 emissions and socio economic benefits in its approvals paperwork. •	Tax: the current Energy Profits Levy (EPL) runs to 1 April 2030, keeping the marginal rate at 78% until then; after that the new Oil and Gas Price Mechanism (OGPM) only adds extra tax when prices are unusually high, otherwise the rate reverts to 40%. •	This makes it attractive to invest capital before 2030 (getting up to roughly 78–84% tax relief on spend) and then enjoy lower tax on production in the 2030s, assuming prices are not extreme. Buchan / Greater Buchan Area •	Buchan is described as a material project with about 70 mmboe 2P at field level and over 100 mmboe including wider GBA upside. •	The JV is updating the Environmental Impact Assessment for the new Scope 3 rules, and doing value engineering on drilling and subsea to optimise capex before sanction. •	Western Isles FPSO is now only one of several development options being re screened in 2026, reflecting the delay and NEO’s expanded asset base. •	JOG and partners will apply to extend the P2498 (Buchan) and P2170 (Verbier area) licence terms, with FDP and EIA already submitted so the regulator is well briefed. •	They have relinquished the riskiest part of P2170 to cut licence fees by about 40%, while keeping discoveries and better prospects. Strategy and M&A •	JOG says it is “right sized”: small, nimble, and focused on growing in a “smart and sustainable” way. •	Priority 1: unlock the organic value in GBA (Buchan + Verbier/J2 etc). •	Priority 2: look for accretive acquisitions, ideally producing UK assets that bring cash flow and let them use over £100m of tax allowances (including EPL losses); they are also looking at international producing assets if they fit and use capital sensibly. Financial position •	Year end 2025 cash is about £11m, with no debt. •	After cutting running costs by c.50% in 2024, total cash spend in 2025 is ~£1.5m, with 2026 expected to be slightly less if nothing major changes. •	JOG’s 20% share of Buchan capex is fully carried by NEO and Serica, and JOG is due a further US$20m in cash when Buchan’s FDP is approved and all consents are granted. In short, the message is: the policy clouds have cleared, Buchan is being optimised rather than rushed, JOG’s big partners are getting even bigger, and JOG itself is lean, funded, carried on Buchan and hunting dea

data.author: JB65
data.content: I really don’t believe some of the criticism being levied at AB is justified. I am a long-term holder in JOG - have been invested since 2017 - and this is now one of only two investments I have in the markets. Having invested steadily over the past 8 years I am of course disappointed that the current share price is well below my average break-even level, I certainly never anticipated I would have been looking at a 10 year plus period to get a return on my holding. However I believe AB and his team have done little wrong in taking the business to where it is at now. They have successfully negotiated 2 farm-out deals with major players who have long-term interests in North Sea O&G, and have retained a 20% fully funded carry to first oil.  Maybe the Board were premature in taking bonuses on completion of the farm out agreements but they have little control over the ludicrous attitude being shown to the whole Oil & Gas industry by our incumbent incompetent Government. Analysts are still positive for the long-term success of JOG, particularly given we now have clarification of the taxation treatment post EPL. I share this view but certainly have sympathy for long term investors like myself who can only sit tight and remain patient!

data.author: Bob333
data.content: CONT: In short, the message is: the policy clouds have cleared, Buchan is being optimised rather than rushed, JOG’s big partners are getting even bigger, and JOG itself is lean, funded, carried on Buchan and hunting deals that monetise its tax shield. DYOR!

data.author: Bob333
data.content: Big picture •	Government has finished its long consultations, so the rules on environment and tax are now known, which lets companies plan long term projects like Buchan more sensibly. •	JOG’s partners (NEO and Serica) have bulked up via M&A, making Buchan part of two much larger, better capitalised UK North Sea portfolios. •	JOG itself has cut costs, has no debt, a modest but adequate cash pile, and a fully carried 20% stake in Buchan plus a further milestone payment due at FDP approval. UK tax and regulation •	Environmental rules now require Buchan to include Scope 3 emissions and socio economic benefits in its approvals paperwork. •	Tax: the current Energy Profits Levy (EPL) runs to 1 April 2030, keeping the marginal rate at 78% until then; after that the new Oil and Gas Price Mechanism (OGPM) only adds extra tax when prices are unusually high, otherwise the rate reverts to 40%. •	This makes it attractive to invest capital before 2030 (getting up to roughly 78–84% tax relief on spend) and then enjoy lower tax on production in the 2030s, assuming prices are not extreme. Buchan / Greater Buchan Area •	Buchan is described as a material project with about 70 mmboe 2P at field level and over 100 mmboe including wider GBA upside. •	The JV is updating the Environmental Impact Assessment for the new Scope 3 rules, and doing value engineering on drilling and subsea to optimise capex before sanction. •	Western Isles FPSO is now only one of several development options being re screened in 2026, reflecting the delay and NEO’s expanded asset base. •	JOG and partners will apply to extend the P2498 (Buchan) and P2170 (Verbier area) licence terms, with FDP and EIA already submitted so the regulator is well briefed. •	They have relinquished the riskiest part of P2170 to cut licence fees by about 40%, while keeping discoveries and better prospects. Strategy and M&A •	JOG says it is “right sized”: small, nimble, and focused on growing in a “smart and sustainable” way. •	Priority 1: unlock the organic value in GBA (Buchan + Verbier/J2 etc). •	Priority 2: look for accretive acquisitions, ideally producing UK assets that bring cash flow and let them use over £100m of tax allowances (including EPL losses); they are also looking at international producing assets if they fit and use capital sensibly. Financial position •	Year end 2025 cash is about £11m, with no debt. •	After cutting running costs by c.50% in 2024, total cash spend in 2025 is ~£1.5m, with 2026 expected to be slightly less if nothing major changes. •	JOG’s 20% share of Buchan capex is fully carried by NEO and Serica, and JOG is due a further US$20m in cash when Buchan’s FDP is approved and all consents are granted. In short, the message is: the policy clouds have cleared, Buchan is being optimised rather than rushed, JOG’s big partners are getting even bigger, and JOG itself is lean, funded, carried on Buchan and hunting dea

data.author: JB65
data.content: I really don’t believe some of the criticism being levied at AB is justified. I am a long-term holder in JOG - have been invested since 2017 - and this is now one of only two investments I have in the markets. Having invested steadily over the past 8 years I am of course disappointed that the current share price is well below my average break-even level, I certainly never anticipated I would have been looking at a 10 year plus period to get a return on my holding. However I believe AB and his team have done little wrong in taking the business to where it is at now. They have successfully negotiated 2 farm-out deals with major players who have long-term interests in North Sea O&G, and have retained a 20% fully funded carry to first oil.  Maybe the Board were premature in taking bonuses on completion of the farm out agreements but they have little control over the ludicrous attitude being shown to the whole Oil & Gas industry by our incumbent incompetent Government. Analysts are still positive for the long-term success of JOG, particularly given we now have clarification of the taxation treatment post EPL. I share this view but certainly have sympathy for long term investors like myself who can only sit tight and remain patient!

data.author: Didas
data.content: I have been looking back at charts. It has been three years since JOG peaked at 332p and five years ago we were at 151p and today we are at a miserable 85p. The recent update has not supported the price. For those of us who have held for many years, it has been money locked in and most of us are likely sitting on losses. Both current and previous governments have caused great uncertainty and their own ideologies and fear of losing their privileged positions, rather than economic benefits to the UK and domestic sustainability, has meant that O&G investors are sitting on their hands in the NS and prioritising extraction elsewhere. It would be good to hear what NEO+ has to say as the major operator.  How high a priority is Buchan in their plans? Exactly what time schedule are we looking at for FDP approval and FID. How dependent is it on any adjustment to the tax issue? I imagine that JOG Board is totally hand tied and hence have been reducing their cost base. However, all these years later,  a market capitalisation of only £28m, no income and a bank balance diminishing every year. We seem to be a one trick pony and I cannot see any foray into other producing activities would be possible given our balance sheet. Apologies if i am sounding depressed!

data.author: Bob333
data.content: CONT: In short, the message is: the policy clouds have cleared, Buchan is being optimised rather than rushed, JOG’s big partners are getting even bigger, and JOG itself is lean, funded, carried on Buchan and hunting deals that monetise its tax shield. DYOR!

data.author: Bob333
data.content: Big picture •	Government has finished its long consultations, so the rules on environment and tax are now known, which lets companies plan long term projects like Buchan more sensibly. •	JOG’s partners (NEO and Serica) have bulked up via M&A, making Buchan part of two much larger, better capitalised UK North Sea portfolios. •	JOG itself has cut costs, has no debt, a modest but adequate cash pile, and a fully carried 20% stake in Buchan plus a further milestone payment due at FDP approval. UK tax and regulation •	Environmental rules now require Buchan to include Scope 3 emissions and socio economic benefits in its approvals paperwork. •	Tax: the current Energy Profits Levy (EPL) runs to 1 April 2030, keeping the marginal rate at 78% until then; after that the new Oil and Gas Price Mechanism (OGPM) only adds extra tax when prices are unusually high, otherwise the rate reverts to 40%. •	This makes it attractive to invest capital before 2030 (getting up to roughly 78–84% tax relief on spend) and then enjoy lower tax on production in the 2030s, assuming prices are not extreme. Buchan / Greater Buchan Area •	Buchan is described as a material project with about 70 mmboe 2P at field level and over 100 mmboe including wider GBA upside. •	The JV is updating the Environmental Impact Assessment for the new Scope 3 rules, and doing value engineering on drilling and subsea to optimise capex before sanction. •	Western Isles FPSO is now only one of several development options being re screened in 2026, reflecting the delay and NEO’s expanded asset base. •	JOG and partners will apply to extend the P2498 (Buchan) and P2170 (Verbier area) licence terms, with FDP and EIA already submitted so the regulator is well briefed. •	They have relinquished the riskiest part of P2170 to cut licence fees by about 40%, while keeping discoveries and better prospects. Strategy and M&A •	JOG says it is “right sized”: small, nimble, and focused on growing in a “smart and sustainable” way. •	Priority 1: unlock the organic value in GBA (Buchan + Verbier/J2 etc). •	Priority 2: look for accretive acquisitions, ideally producing UK assets that bring cash flow and let them use over £100m of tax allowances (including EPL losses); they are also looking at international producing assets if they fit and use capital sensibly. Financial position •	Year end 2025 cash is about £11m, with no debt. •	After cutting running costs by c.50% in 2024, total cash spend in 2025 is ~£1.5m, with 2026 expected to be slightly less if nothing major changes. •	JOG’s 20% share of Buchan capex is fully carried by NEO and Serica, and JOG is due a further US$20m in cash when Buchan’s FDP is approved and all consents are granted. In short, the message is: the policy clouds have cleared, Buchan is being optimised rather than rushed, JOG’s big partners are getting even bigger, and JOG itself is lean, funded, carried on Buchan and hunting dea

data.content: CONT: In short, the message is: the policy clouds have cleared, Buchan is being optimised rather than rushed, JOG’s big partners are getting even bigger, and JOG itself is lean, funded, carried on Buchan and hunting deals that monetise its tax shield. DYOR!

data.author: Bob333
data.content: Big picture •	Government has finished its long consultations, so the rules on environment and tax are now known, which lets companies plan long term projects like Buchan more sensibly. •	JOG’s partners (NEO and Serica) have bulked up via M&A, making Buchan part of two much larger, better capitalised UK North Sea portfolios. •	JOG itself has cut costs, has no debt, a modest but adequate cash pile, and a fully carried 20% stake in Buchan plus a further milestone payment due at FDP approval. UK tax and regulation •	Environmental rules now require Buchan to include Scope 3 emissions and socio economic benefits in its approvals paperwork. •	Tax: the current Energy Profits Levy (EPL) runs to 1 April 2030, keeping the marginal rate at 78% until then; after that the new Oil and Gas Price Mechanism (OGPM) only adds extra tax when prices are unusually high, otherwise the rate reverts to 40%. •	This makes it attractive to invest capital before 2030 (getting up to roughly 78–84% tax relief on spend) and then enjoy lower tax on production in the 2030s, assuming prices are not extreme. Buchan / Greater Buchan Area •	Buchan is described as a material project with about 70 mmboe 2P at field level and over 100 mmboe including wider GBA upside. •	The JV is updating the Environmental Impact Assessment for the new Scope 3 rules, and doing value engineering on drilling and subsea to optimise capex before sanction. •	Western Isles FPSO is now only one of several development options being re screened in 2026, reflecting the delay and NEO’s expanded asset base. •	JOG and partners will apply to extend the P2498 (Buchan) and P2170 (Verbier area) licence terms, with FDP and EIA already submitted so the regulator is well briefed. •	They have relinquished the riskiest part of P2170 to cut licence fees by about 40%, while keeping discoveries and better prospects. Strategy and M&A •	JOG says it is “right sized”: small, nimble, and focused on growing in a “smart and sustainable” way. •	Priority 1: unlock the organic value in GBA (Buchan + Verbier/J2 etc). •	Priority 2: look for accretive acquisitions, ideally producing UK assets that bring cash flow and let them use over £100m of tax allowances (including EPL losses); they are also looking at international producing assets if they fit and use capital sensibly. Financial position •	Year end 2025 cash is about £11m, with no debt. •	After cutting running costs by c.50% in 2024, total cash spend in 2025 is ~£1.5m, with 2026 expected to be slightly less if nothing major changes. •	JOG’s 20% share of Buchan capex is fully carried by NEO and Serica, and JOG is due a further US$20m in cash when Buchan’s FDP is approved and all consents are granted. In short, the message is: the policy clouds have cleared, Buchan is being optimised rather than rushed, JOG’s big partners are getting even bigger, and JOG itself is lean, funded, carried on Buchan and hunting dea

data.author: Bob333
data.content: CONT: In short, the message is: the policy clouds have cleared, Buchan is being optimised rather than rushed, JOG’s big partners are getting even bigger, and JOG itself is lean, funded, carried on Buchan and hunting deals that monetise its tax shield. DYOR!

data.author: Bob333
data.content: Big picture •	Government has finished its long consultations, so the rules on environment and tax are now known, which lets companies plan long term projects like Buchan more sensibly. •	JOG’s partners (NEO and Serica) have bulked up via M&A, making Buchan part of two much larger, better capitalised UK North Sea portfolios. •	JOG itself has cut costs, has no debt, a modest but adequate cash pile, and a fully carried 20% stake in Buchan plus a further milestone payment due at FDP approval. UK tax and regulation •	Environmental rules now require Buchan to include Scope 3 emissions and socio economic benefits in its approvals paperwork. •	Tax: the current Energy Profits Levy (EPL) runs to 1 April 2030, keeping the marginal rate at 78% until then; after that the new Oil and Gas Price Mechanism (OGPM) only adds extra tax when prices are unusually high, otherwise the rate reverts to 40%. •	This makes it attractive to invest capital before 2030 (getting up to roughly 78–84% tax relief on spend) and then enjoy lower tax on production in the 2030s, assuming prices are not extreme. Buchan / Greater Buchan Area •	Buchan is described as a material project with about 70 mmboe 2P at field level and over 100 mmboe including wider GBA upside. •	The JV is updating the Environmental Impact Assessment for the new Scope 3 rules, and doing value engineering on drilling and subsea to optimise capex before sanction. •	Western Isles FPSO is now only one of several development options being re screened in 2026, reflecting the delay and NEO’s expanded asset base. •	JOG and partners will apply to extend the P2498 (Buchan) and P2170 (Verbier area) licence terms, with FDP and EIA already submitted so the regulator is well briefed. •	They have relinquished the riskiest part of P2170 to cut licence fees by about 40%, while keeping discoveries and better prospects. Strategy and M&A •	JOG says it is “right sized”: small, nimble, and focused on growing in a “smart and sustainable” way. •	Priority 1: unlock the organic value in GBA (Buchan + Verbier/J2 etc). •	Priority 2: look for accretive acquisitions, ideally producing UK assets that bring cash flow and let them use over £100m of tax allowances (including EPL losses); they are also looking at international producing assets if they fit and use capital sensibly. Financial position •	Year end 2025 cash is about £11m, with no debt. •	After cutting running costs by c.50% in 2024, total cash spend in 2025 is ~£1.5m, with 2026 expected to be slightly less if nothing major changes. •	JOG’s 20% share of Buchan capex is fully carried by NEO and Serica, and JOG is due a further US$20m in cash when Buchan’s FDP is approved and all consents are granted. In short, the message is: the policy clouds have cleared, Buchan is being optimised rather than rushed, JOG’s big partners are getting even bigger, and JOG itself is lean, funded, carried on Buchan and hunting dea

data.author: JB65
data.content: I really don’t believe some of the criticism being levied at AB is justified. I am a long-term holder in JOG - have been invested since 2017 - and this is now one of only two investments I have in the markets. Having invested steadily over the past 8 years I am of course disappointed that the current share price is well below my average break-even level, I certainly never anticipated I would have been looking at a 10 year plus period to get a return on my holding. However I believe AB and his team have done little wrong in taking the business to where it is at now. They have successfully negotiated 2 farm-out deals with major players who have long-term interests in North Sea O&G, and have retained a 20% fully funded carry to first oil.  Maybe the Board were premature in taking bonuses on completion of the farm out agreements but they have little control over the ludicrous attitude being shown to the whole Oil & Gas industry by our incumbent incompetent Government. Analysts are still positive for the long-term success of JOG, particularly given we now have clarification of the taxation treatment post EPL. I share this view but certainly have sympathy for long term investors like myself who can only sit tight and remain patient!

data.author: Didas
data.content: I have been looking back at charts. It has been three years since JOG peaked at 332p and five years ago we were at 151p and today we are at a miserable 85p. The recent update has not supported the price. For those of us who have held for many years, it has been money locked in and most of us are likely sitting on losses. Both current and previous governments have caused great uncertainty and their own ideologies and fear of losing their privileged positions, rather than economic benefits to the UK and domestic sustainability, has meant that O&G investors are sitting on their hands in the NS and prioritising extraction elsewhere. It would be good to hear what NEO+ has to say as the major operator.  How high a priority is Buchan in their plans? Exactly what time schedule are we looking at for FDP approval and FID. How dependent is it on any adjustment to the tax issue? I imagine that JOG Board is totally hand tied and hence have been reducing their cost base. However, all these years later,  a market capitalisation of only £28m, no income and a bank balance diminishing every year. We seem to be a one trick pony and I cannot see any foray into other producing activities would be possible given our balance sheet. Apologies if i am sounding depressed!

data.author: Bob333
data.content: CONT: In short, the message is: the policy clouds have cleared, Buchan is being optimised rather than rushed, JOG’s big partners are getting even bigger, and JOG itself is lean, funded, carried on Buchan and hunting deals that monetise its tax shield. DYOR!

data.author: Bob333
data.content: Big picture •	Government has finished its long consultations, so the rules on environment and tax are now known, which lets companies plan long term projects like Buchan more sensibly. •	JOG’s partners (NEO and Serica) have bulked up via M&A, making Buchan part of two much larger, better capitalised UK North Sea portfolios. •	JOG itself has cut costs, has no debt, a modest but adequate cash pile, and a fully carried 20% stake in Buchan plus a further milestone payment due at FDP approval. UK tax and regulation •	Environmental rules now require Buchan to include Scope 3 emissions and socio economic benefits in its approvals paperwork. •	Tax: the current Energy Profits Levy (EPL) runs to 1 April 2030, keeping the marginal rate at 78% until then; after that the new Oil and Gas Price Mechanism (OGPM) only adds extra tax when prices are unusually high, otherwise the rate reverts to 40%. •	This makes it attractive to invest capital before 2030 (getting up to roughly 78–84% tax relief on spend) and then enjoy lower tax on production in the 2030s, assuming prices are not extreme. Buchan / Greater Buchan Area •	Buchan is described as a material project with about 70 mmboe 2P at field level and over 100 mmboe including wider GBA upside. •	The JV is updating the Environmental Impact Assessment for the new Scope 3 rules, and doing value engineering on drilling and subsea to optimise capex before sanction. •	Western Isles FPSO is now only one of several development options being re screened in 2026, reflecting the delay and NEO’s expanded asset base. •	JOG and partners will apply to extend the P2498 (Buchan) and P2170 (Verbier area) licence terms, with FDP and EIA already submitted so the regulator is well briefed. •	They have relinquished the riskiest part of P2170 to cut licence fees by about 40%, while keeping discoveries and better prospects. Strategy and M&A •	JOG says it is “right sized”: small, nimble, and focused on growing in a “smart and sustainable” way. •	Priority 1: unlock the organic value in GBA (Buchan + Verbier/J2 etc). •	Priority 2: look for accretive acquisitions, ideally producing UK assets that bring cash flow and let them use over £100m of tax allowances (including EPL losses); they are also looking at international producing assets if they fit and use capital sensibly. Financial position •	Year end 2025 cash is about £11m, with no debt. •	After cutting running costs by c.50% in 2024, total cash spend in 2025 is ~£1.5m, with 2026 expected to be slightly less if nothing major changes. •	JOG’s 20% share of Buchan capex is fully carried by NEO and Serica, and JOG is due a further US$20m in cash when Buchan’s FDP is approved and all consents are granted. In short, the message is: the policy clouds have cleared, Buchan is being optimised rather than rushed, JOG’s big partners are getting even bigger, and JOG itself is lean, funded, carried on Buchan and hunting dea

data.author: JB65
data.content: I really don’t believe some of the criticism being levied at AB is justified. I am a long-term holder in JOG - have been invested since 2017 - and this is now one of only two investments I have in the markets. Having invested steadily over the past 8 years I am of course disappointed that the current share price is well below my average break-even level, I certainly never anticipated I would have been looking at a 10 year plus period to get a return on my holding. However I believe AB and his team have done little wrong in taking the business to where it is at now. They have successfully negotiated 2 farm-out deals with major players who have long-term interests in North Sea O&G, and have retained a 20% fully funded carry to first oil.  Maybe the Board were premature in taking bonuses on completion of the farm out agreements but they have little control over the ludicrous attitude being shown to the whole Oil & Gas industry by our incumbent incompetent Government. Analysts are still positive for the long-term success of JOG, particularly given we now have clarification of the taxation treatment post EPL. I share this view but certainly have sympathy for long term investors like myself who can only sit tight and remain patient!

The only hint of potential bottoming is the steady stream of routine disclosures, which could indicate the company is simply staying afloat while waiting for a catalyst.
